Description: Knob for a piece of furniture or ear-plug: in translucent olive-green glass, matt surface, intended for attachment to a piece of furniture. The shape, a circular convex top followed by a central concave area and terminating in another convex area, exactly follows the shape of the hard limestone knobs attached to wooden doors of houses at El-Amarna by means of a bronze nail. The front convex surface is inlaid at its centre with a prefabricated circular band of black and white cord. Within and surrounding this impressed detail small drops of opaque white, orange, black, and turquoise-blue glass have been dropped from the end of a mandril - essentially a spatter technique. The circumferences of the central concave area are outlined with prefabricated white and black cord. At the centre of the under-surface is a cylindrical opening which reaches about halfway up the knob.
Curator's comments: Such knobs are known only from the time indicated above and their use seems to have been restricted to products made by royal cabinet-makers.
Bibliographic references: Tait 1991 / Five Thousand Years of Glass (fig.36, p.36)
